fields.summary: Bamboo artifacts don't get collected if they are located into directories

fields.description:
As referenced in JSP-79461 and BAM-10379 , I have an automated script which retrieves artifacts from Bamboo via wget for use in other Bamboo plans. This page-scraping script is a hacky kludge to get around Bamboo's lack of an RSS feed for a plan's artifacts. With the release of 4.0.1, a change was introduced in the Bamboo plan artifact page which broke this script. There is now a snippet of HTML code which reads:

Build: #1234 was successful

wget saves this as a regular file at 'bamboo/browse/PROJECT-PLAN-1234' Later in the page, the individual artifacts are referenced, eg: share-name wget attempts to create the directories 'bamboo/browse/PROJECT-PLAN-1234/artifact/shared/share-name', but fails due to a previously-created file matching one of the parent directories, 'bamboo/browse/PROJECT-PLAN-1234'. This makes the fetch of the artifacts fail, stopping our other bamboo plans which depend on having the artifacts to play with. Please restore the trailing '/' to the link beneath 'Build was successful' as per previous versions.
fields.summary: Links in artifact listing changed, breaking automated fetch behaviour

fields.description: I tried artifact sharing with the default 0022 umask, but Bamboo changes the file permissions from original 755 to 644. Changing the umask value didn't make any difference.

fields.summary: Add Linked JIRA Issue does not accept multiple JIRA issue keys

fields.description:
I run a pipeline featuring the following stages:

1. compile
2. run unit tests
3. create release
4. run integration tests
5. deploy to uat
6. deploy to acc
7. deploy to prod

To make sure the same revision and compiled code is used throughout all stages I create an artifact from the whole working copy (**) in stage 1. This is used in all subsequent stages.

However, because the artifact is loaded from the server for every stage, this setup is very slow.

It could be adressed by either keeping a local copy of the artifacts on the agent server itself or have the possibility to reuse the same working copy throughout the different stages.

I definitely NOT want to checkout and compile code in every stage as it will slow down the pipeline and increase the risk of unwanted side-effects caused by redoing previous steps.

Nor does running a local agent help as the server should not run any builds at all as the machine will need all its resources for managing plans for the whole company.
fields.summary: Improve pipeline performance

fields.description:
The Bamboo documentation linked from OnDemand explains how to use EBS, but doens't mention that things are different for OnDemand. For an OnDemand customer to use EBS with Bamboo, they will need to create a support request containing the cert and pk pem files. Maybe a reference to http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=253231643.

The page that should include this is at least http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO030/Configuring+Elastic+Instances+to+use+the+EBS - This matches the version running in AOD. Maybe other versions as well?
fields.summary: Add information to Bamboo EBS page about OnDemand

fields.description:

I would expect that the total plan time would be at least as much as the longest job time.

See attached screenshots.
fields.summary: Plan level and Job level time estimates do not match

fields.description:
I added a Mail Server, and an email arrives in my inbox when I test the configuration.

Now I'm testing customized email notifications. To do so, I followed these steps:
# Edited the plan notification configuration:
** Event: All Builds Completed
** Recipient Type: Email Address
** Email Address: fkraemer@atlassian.com
(I also tried with Recipient Type = User / User = Felipe Kraemer, whose email is fkraemer@atlassian.com)
# Followed [this document|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO40/Modifying+notification+templates] this way:
## Created the {{notification-templates}} directory inside the existing {{BAMBOO_HOME/templates}} directory (Shouldn't it already exist by default?)
## Moved (instead of copied) {{BuildCompletedHtmlEmail.ftl}} and {{BuildCompletedTextEmail.ftl}} from {{WEB-INF/classes/notification-templates}} to {{BAMBOO_HOME/templates/notification-templates}}
## Edited these files adding {{"This is my test"}} outside of any logic tests to make sure it would be displayed
## Saved the changes
## Restarted the Bamboo instance, although our documentation says this is not necessary
## Manually triggered a build, which finished successful.
## *Default notification* arrived at the inbox, instead of a *customized* notification.

The customized notification should have arrived at the inbox, containing {{"This is my test"}} text. 
It's like it disregarded the customization and used the default notification templates, but I *moved* them from the default directory {{WEB-INF/classes/notification-templates}} to {{BAMBOO_HOME/templates/notification-templates}}, so they don't exist in the default notification anymore.

Please see the customized templates attached.
No errors were reported in the Bamboo logs.
fields.summary: Customized notifications not being sent

fields.description:
Bamboo's current security model is insufficient for segregating development teams working on different security projects. Currently project A can be made to build on project B's build agent and a rogue developer in project A could use a modified build script to collect project B's source code from the agent's working copy.
The option of deleting working copies after each build relies on manual (and therefore error prone) procedures and incurs significant performance overheads.
I suggest providing an administrative function to dedicate build agents to specific projects which has the effect that the dedicated project is then *only* built on those dedicated agents, and no other project can be built on them.
fields.summary: Ensure builds are tied to dedicated agents for security

fields.description: If someone would like to treat master's plan as the same "citizen category" as branches, then there is no such place in Bamboo to list all plan-branches (inc. master) equally. For example in Branches summary dashboard one can see all the branches with their last build status + misc data (http://localhost:8085/bamboo/browse/PP-PP/branches), but the master's plan is not included in the dashboard. If someone looks at plan summary, then he will be able to see recent history of *master* plan (main panel) and last build status only (right-bottom panel). Not quite consistent if you treat all plan-branches (including master) equally, because for example all of them must be green (i.e, they aren't feature branches, but for example different-jira-version-branches).
fields.summary: A page where one could see all plan-branches including master plan.

fields.description:
If we create a plan along with plan-branches, then in breadcrumb selector (see attachment) we will see something like:
* default <-- hardcoded text (branch.master.title)
* branch 1 name 
* branch 2 name
* branch 3 name
etc etc

Thing is that the 'default' name is not intuitive for some use-cases. For example imagine a plan that tests a plugin for jira. Each branch in the plugin repository corresponds with different jira version (trunk -> 5.x, 4.x, 3.x). Lets assume the trunk of the repository is set up to work against jira 5.x. So, the branches selector list will look in this example like:
* default
* 4.x
* 3.x

This is not clear at the first glance what that 'default' is. The more intuitive list would look like:
* 5.x (let's assume the master plan name is "5.x")
* 4.x
* 3.x

I'm not 100% sure what should be displayed instead of the hardcoded "default" but using the master's plan name could be a good shot for the beginning (as it is similarly displayed in Branch Integration selectboxes: "default: planName"; "branch1" ; "branch2").
fields.summary: In breadcrumb's branch selector the master's plan should display itself as something different than "default"

fields.description:
As part of one of our builds we require a X server running.  I'm trying to start Xvfb however when I'm adding this to job as a command or script it hangs and waits for Xvbf to finish instead of going onto the next job in the stage.

How would I be able to start Xvbf in the background and let the Job continue?

I've tried using &, && in a script.  When using it as a command I can not as this is not a valid argument to Xvfb.  Am I missing something?  Is this possible?
fields.summary: Starting a command in the background

fields.description:
It would be great if there would be a ${bamboo.projectKey} variable. We follow very strict naming conventions, which results in the project key being used in any and all parts of our development infrastructure, including Bamboo and Subversion.

As such, this would allow us to use Subversion URLs such as http://svn.company.tld/${bamboo.projectKey}/trunk to automatically point to  the correct SVN repository, without having to (manually) change the URL in each and every plan.
fields.summary: Implement ${bamboo.projectKey} variable

fields.summary: Create Job hangs with a loading spinner

fields.description:
Screencast: http://screencast.com/t/0aCGjkCIOB3

On BEAC: https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CAV-REVIEW-137

I try to stop the build but nothing happens.  Is Bamboo waiting for the build to reach the front of the queue before it's stopped?  Seems inefficient.

There is a JS error from the jira issue collector on page load, but it seems unrelated - stopPlan.action is still called.
fields.summary: Can't stop a queued build?

fields.description:
Use case:

1. Start a set of Elastic agents with configuration C 
2. Delete capability X present on configuration C
3. Run a build that requires X and is going to expand its value on a build task

Unexpected output:
1. Agents from (1) get the build and fail to expand C!! 

Hypothesis: 
It looks like agents think they have C so they grab it from the queue but then the server doesn't know anything about C therefore failing to expand the capability...
fields.summary: Capabilities on Elastic images are out of synch when deleting them
JUnit test parser cannot handle files with different extensions
Redirect loop when clicking top-left nav bar

fields.description: Clicking a menu such as Run, then clicking the menu again to close it, then again to reopen it does nothing.  In fact, once I open a menu I cannot open any other menu either.  I'm doing a lot of reloading the UI so that I can open a menu when I've opened the wrong one first.  It's quite shocking how often I run into this.  Apparently I'm not very good at opening the correct menu and just selecting the thing I want.
fields.summary: Menu cannot be reopened

fields.description:
Created a KB regarding this issue: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Database+Corruption++-+query+did+not+return+a+unique+result

However, I wasn't able to reproduce the problem.

fields.description:
With BAM-11354 solved, I gave git submodule support another go. It doesn't work for submodules that require SSH private key authentication. Please see the following output fro]m https://staging-bamboo.atlassian.com/download/PUPPETCIDELTA-MASTER-DELTA/build_logs/PUPPETCIDELTA-MASTER-DELTA-877.log

Please see [^output.txt] for the stack
fields.summary: Git submodule support not working for SSH private key authenticated checkouts

fields.description:
The problem seems to be trailing whitespace on the author name

For example:
{code}
<author>
   <id>1638401</id>
   <name>John Johnson</name>
</author>
...
<author>
   <id>5406721</id>
   <name>John Johnson   </name>
</author>
{code}
fields.summary: Duplicate authors in database export cause import to fail from HSQL to MySQL

fields.description:
As per topic.  Would it be possible to have integrated support for Opencover reports the same way you do with NCover?  Ncover is not free, Opencover is.

It would be handy to track coverage easily across builds and good to see track record chart displayed on the plan page.
fields.summary: OpenCover coverage reports

fields.description:
Originating from: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-6943
JGit works with the same settings. We need to confirm if it's a bug and fix.
fields.summary: Problem when using native Git + ssh + password authentication

fields.description:
if I am running a build and configuring one of it's jobs at the same time, clicking on the running build will result in this invalid link:

https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CRUCHG-CHAIN-BUILD-2109

when it should be:
https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CRUCHG-CHAIN-JOB1-2109
fields.summary: going to a running build from a job configuration doesn't work

fields.description: From the build result summary screen, there should be an option to create a JIRA issue for this build.
fields.summary: As a build engineer, I can create JIRA issues from Bamboo so I can assign responsibility for broken builds

fields.description: Please add functionality to be able to remove or add items to the release. For example, if I have a project version in Jira set to 1.2.3 and 5 tasks assigned for the version. If I Fix the first 3 tasks and not the last 2 tasks as the last 2 tasks are in progress, I want to be able to instruct Bamboo to only build the binaries with the first 3 tasks and ignore the last 2 tasks. So that the functionality provided by last 2 tasks does not get rolled out.
fields.summary: Add functionality to manage the content on the release after integrating jira and bamboo

fields.description: When a build is queued it add a blank box to the wallboard. See screenshots
fields.summary: Builds queued cause a blank box in the wallboard

fields.description:
Please include the JIRA variables to [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+global,+plan+or+build-specific+variables] page the same way as they are mentioned under the "Runtime, Plan and Global variables" link of the Tasks page in Bamboo.

Also, please mention that [these JIRA variables|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-9519] can be accessed from a Bamoo build only when that build was triggered by [releasing a version in JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=245827028].
fields.summary: Please update the documentation to include the JIRA variables to the list Bamboo available variable list
XCode plugin doesn't work with Bamboo 4

fields.description: I created a VCS Tagging task and tried to use the ${bamboo.jira.version} variable along with ${bamboo.buildResultKey} variable in the "Tag name" field. ${bamboo.buildResultKey} is getting substituted, but ${bamboo.jira.version}  doesn't even though the variable name is in the list described under "Runtime, Plan and Global variables" link of the Tasks page.
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't substitute JIRA variables/parameters after integrating Bamboo with JIRA

fields.description: If there is an Applink between Bamboo and Stash, Bamboo should be aware of the repositories hosted in Stash.
fields.summary: Make Bamboo aware of repositories in Stash

fields.description:
Should be able to trigger builds via Stash. We could do something smart here and be branch aware.

The way I believe this should work
# Uses Application Links between Stash and Bamboo
# When a commit is made, it posts the commit and some repository metadata to the Bamboo server
# Custom endpoint on the Bamboo side that does a database query to figure out what plans use the repository posted to it
# Runs change detection for the plans that match
fields.summary: Stash should be able to trigger builds

fields.description:
The UI to provide AWS key files has changed. Now we got a "Key files location" drop-down menu instead of 2 text fields to specify the location of these key files, but the drop-down is empty, potentially blocking providing the key files to Bamboo server.

Please see a screen video here: http://screencast.com/t/agXuB7ltwY
fields.summary: "Key files location" drop-down is empty, blocking providing AWS key files
Exceptions thrown to screen after enabling spot instance support

fields.description: But there is no error in Bamboo log though.
fields.summary: Accessing UPM leads to a blank page

fields.description: After using branches for a while, it seems that you want to have a different schedule than the main build quite often
fields.summary: Allow build trigger strategies of branches to be overriden

fields.description: Provide ability to export some of Bamboo plans form one Bamboo version(old version) and import into the other (new version) without losing the existing plans in the new version.
fields.summary: Ability to export/import some Bamboo plans from one version to the other

fields.description:
External plugin developers would like to run their func test builds in the elastic cloud, but we provide no assistance or pointers in how this may be configured.  It would be an awesome win if we could provide some setup instructions in the official documentation.

[https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/42824/atlassian-please-write-a-selenium-on-elastic-bamboo-tutorial]
fields.summary: Please provide documentation on configuring WebDriver on elastic Bamboo agents

fields.description:
There are several issues associated with the current Tunnel version:
# when used together with Squid (OnDemand deployment), it tries to keep idle (unused) tunnel connections for too long, leading to timeouts at tunnel level and errors and tunneled protocol level (SSL handshake errors, wire format negotiation errors, broken pipe errors, class loading errors). Some of these errors cause retries, some take down the agents
# there are some resource leaks, leading to sockets hanging in CLOSE_WAIT state
# in some cases, the data forwarding seems to be stuck for a couple of seconds, leading to dropped heartbeats (and probably no bad consequences) - the current assumption is that the tunneled connection needs to be flushed more aggressively.
fields.summary: Elastic Tunnel problems

fields.description:
As discussed in here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-6790?focusedCommentId=2515094&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-2515094

Possible solution could be configurable timeout or retrying.
fields.summary: Remote agent can fail downloading classpath JARs when server busy

fields.description:
For example, if there is a service on the environment that only one build can use at a time it would be nice if Bamboo could prevent other builds which share the requirement from building at the same time.

Bamboo could allow an administrator to define Resources which can be locked when a build runs.
fields.summary: Prevent plans from running simultaneously when using a shared resource

fields.description: Ability to run any manual stage from the build result, even if there are stages that have not been run yet.
fields.summary: Ability to run any manual stage from the build result

fields.description: Run a build when an issue has been moved to the finished column (or another column) in the greenhopper work view.
fields.summary: Run build when issue has been moved to finished in Greenhopper

fields.description:
From James:
"This page needs to explain the differences between build-in git and the native git. (need to use native for submodules, automatic branch detection and automatic merging).

We should also explain how to define the git capability. Couldn't hurt linking to the Git download page."

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO40/Git
fields.summary: Improve documentation for Git repos

fields.description: When Bamboo detects a new branch and creates a corresponding Plan branch, the vcs creator of the branch should be automatically favourite the new plan branch so that it appears on their wallboard and receive notifications.
fields.summary: Branch creator should automatically favourite a Plan Branch

fields.description:
I usually check the activity stream for each of Atlassian products on JAC once a day to keep up to date with any issues other customers might be having.
A couple of weeks ago, I started seeing a lot of build information in the Bamboo stream specifically. It's not something I'm interested in at all and it makes it more difficult to see the updates I am interested in. Is there a way to get rid of it?
fields.summary: Bamboo activity stream on JAC shows unwanted build info with broken image links

fields.description: When configuring the [automatic build labeling|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO40/Configuring+automatic+labelling+of+job+build+results], the label is not shown in the list of the build labels after running the plan. However, after clicking the Labels link from the "Build Result Summary" page, and navigating to the Project link, the label is shown. Clicking the label brings the correct build results.
fields.summary: Bamboo automatic build labeling doesn't work properly

fields.description:
MSBuild cannot create temporary files when running as a system service. This is likely to effect other build systems too.

We should recommend customers that they should run Bamboo agents windows services under a new user with admin privileges.
fields.summary: Improve installation recommendations for running builds under a windows service.

fields.description: Bamboo restarts while builds are in progress are painful. It would be good if there were a way to put Bamboo in a pre-maintenance mode where it stops accepting new builds but can still complete in-progress ones.
fields.summary: "Nice" restart/shutdown or maintenance mode

fields.description: When looking at the table of plans on a project page, I'd like to be able to sort either alphabetically (currently the hardcoded default) or by the most recent build date (ascending or descending) by clicking column headers.
fields.summary: Sortable dashboard columns
Bamboo fails to save Global Permissions when trying to edit an LDAP group containing special characters(like '&')

fields.description:
The bamboo-dotnet-plugin is written as plugins V1. It should be migrated to v2 so it can be installed without a restart.

 

This might require taking a closer look at ReportCollector plugin point (which registers in an unusual way).
fields.summary: .NET plugin cannot be installed or upgraded without restart

fields.description: Starting a build that's meant to checkout the code from github results in a runtime exception
fields.summary: Runtime exception on github checkout

fields.description:
If you have a manual stage which only contains disabled jobs.  And a stage after than with a job.  When you press play on the manual stage, it doesn't work.

Tor reproduce, this may or may not require a stage prior to the manual stage with only disabled jobs.
fields.summary: Latter Stages dont get run if a manual stage only has disabled jobs

fields.description:
The OnDemand header renders with no context in bamboo 4. This seems to be a direct consequence of the changes made here https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-1712 (which are not in bamboo 3.0.4-studio-x) to explicitly clean up the context.

Suspicion is that the filter chain is cleaned up before sitemesh is invoked, and we presume the header is rendered (via the 'top-navigation-plugin' point) by sitemesh.
fields.summary: Header renders without context in OnDemand (for bamboo 4)

fields.description:
If you delete a job which is executing it asks if you want to stop the builds. Click confirm. You then get  taken to the job summary page. 

The job summary page is quite confusing by itself now -> without the left hand nav and without proper breadcrumbs.
fields.summary: Deleting Job when executing redirects to job summary page.

fields.description:
# Job exists with broken configuration
# delete job
# recreate job (cloning another with good config) using same name and key
# Task configuration shows the config of the previous job, not the job you cloned.
fields.summary: Recreating (clone) a job immediately after deleting it maintains old task configuration

fields.description: Should take you to somewhere in configuration (stages tab?).
fields.summary: Deleting a job redirects you to the plan summary page

fields.description: For Vcs Branch Details on plan summary
fields.summary: i18n text missing

fields.description:
With previous versions of Bamboo, the "(diffs)" link was available when viewing the Changes tab per build.

However, after upgrading to Bamboo 4.0, that ability seems to have disappeared, despite having the same Actions -> Configure Plan -> Source Repositories -> Plan Repository -> Advanced Options -> Web Repository/URL/module correctly specified. (The absence of the link is highlighted by the red arrow in the attached screenshot.)
fields.summary: File diffs link under the Changes tab no longer displaying after upgrading to Bamboo 4

fields.description:
See this page:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO40/Getting+Bamboo+to+use+the+jetty.xml+file
fields.summary: Check and fix the Bamboo jetty page

fields.description:
# Go to a plan page (https://bamboo.example.com/browse/PROJECT-PLAN)
# Click the "Actions" menu
# "Modify Plan Label"
# Add a label
# Close the dialog. At this point, everything _looks_ OK: the label appears under the plan name.
# Reload the page in the browser
# The label has "moved" to the latest build result
fields.summary: When I add a label to a plan, it actually adds it to the latest build result in that plan

fields.description:
The "story" goes like...

- dev makes a change and mentions the JIRA issue key in the commit message
- Bamboo picks up the change and builds it
- when the build completes, Bamboo adds a comment on any code reviews open against that JIRA issue
fields.summary: As a developer, I can have Bamboo comment on my open Crucible reviews based on build results

fields.description:
In complex (and flaky) plans, sometimes is important to access the job history. Since Bamboo 4 that is no longer possible (unless you know the secret url /job/history).

The plan history doesn't help in a flaky plan, because a job at a final stage is likely to be executed only few times, so you need an incredible amounts of clicks just to access the previous execution's logs.
fields.summary: it's not possible to access the job history from the UI

fields.description:
The original issue is here: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-9680 but it got overrun with a specific plugin error.  So I'm raising another bug to track other plugins + the general problem

The only known JNDI classes used at the moment are LDAP related.

The current strategy is to fix it in individual plugins as it shows up.
fields.summary: Plugins 2 can't access JNDI classes

fields.description: Sometimes users forget their username and/or password after creating the first Bamboo admin account in the setup wizard. In those cases the user has to go over [these steps|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO40/Restoring+passwords+to+recover+admin+users] to reset the account manually from Bamboo DB. Sending an email containing the login credentials will provide a better user experience.
fields.summary: Send an email to the Bamboo admin after the admin account is created in the setup wizard

fields.description: If a plan gets disabled, even if there are unbuilt changes in the source repository that this plan is configured to use, that shouldn't block a child plan from triggering (in case the dependency is configured with "Block build if parent Plans have unbuilt changes" option).
fields.summary: Disabled plans should ignore dependency configurations

Dependency Build variables are not substituted

fields.description:
Using the embedded jGit does not allow the new 4.0 features to work.

Our docs are not mentioning it anywhere.
fields.summary: Make clear in the Docs that the new Branch and Merge features work only when native Git is used

fields.description: When Bamboo and Stash are connected via Applinks, repositories in Stash should be consumable by Bamboo seamlessly without having to configure URLs or credentials.
fields.summary: Stash repository support

fields.description: It may be a philisophical issue, but I like the way that Hudson/Jenkins visually distinguishes a build that runs but has JUnit failures from a build that fails to run or that has JUnit errors.  I'm still learning Bamboo, but all I've seen so far is a binary red/green everywhere.
fields.summary: Visually distinguish between junit failures and build errors.

fields.description:
This comes up very often in support and saw it on Answers as well:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/47137/prevent-bamboo-from-automatically-adding-jdk-capabilities

Essentially - you can disable auto-capability detection, which is desirable if you don't want to run agent with default capabilities.

To do this one needs to restart agent with -DDISABLE_AGENT_AUTO_CAPABILITY_DETECTION=true flag
fields.summary: Add a note about capability detection in the remote agent installation docs

fields.description: Provide an importer for Jenkins so that migrating from Jenkins to Bamboo is easy.
fields.summary: Migrate from Jenkins

fields.description:
I was reconfiguring my repositories to allow for the branches functions and now I can't delete a repository from my plan.  

It looks like you've fixed something for 4.0.1 but I can't see that it's been released yet.  I currently have three repositories on my branch and the build is broken.

I deleted my branches thinking that might help but I still can't delete the repositories off the main build.

I admit I was doing some cleanup and renaming repositories and reconfiguring them.  I'm trying to take advantage of the branching but since I don't use GIT I have to configure the repos manually for each branch.

I don't mind doing that, it's still way better than copying the plan every time you branch the repository.

But I am now essentially unable to build.
fields.summary: Repository Null Error when attempting to delete repo

fields.description:
I had successfully set up a Github repository in 3.3.  After upgrading to 4.0 (and trying to enable submodules for that repository), Bamboo wouldn't load my repositories, complaining that the (still cached) username was invalid.  The plan would still check out the repository and run just fine despite this, though.

I tried deleting the repository and re-creating it so I could make my changes, but I was still unable to get it to load anything.

I then tried to create a regular Git repository that happens to be on Github, which succeeded, although the "Duplicate username" message when a username is provided in the repository URL is rather confusing.
fields.summary: Github: Repository editor complains of "Invalid username" (it's not)

fields.description:
Some development teams only have one plan in Bamboo and multiple branches.  This is a common workflow for a smaller OpenSource project that may have branches for releases and utilize only 3-4 branches at once.  

In these cases, the suppression of branches from the dashboard makes it very hard for developers to see, at a glance what's going on with the two active releases.  In fact, we've had complaints from developers who can no longer FIND branches anymore because the branch icon is so tiny.  ( http://build.tdar.org/bamboo/allPlans.action )

A proposed solution:
 - enable a configuration to list branches on the dashboard
 - leverage metadata about branches (open/closed status in tools like Mercurial, frequency of build, date of last checkin) to determine what branches to show and what branches to hide.

I recognize that some projects have hundreds of branches, and tens of projects, but I think that our case is not uncommon.
fields.summary: always show open branches on dashboard

<project name="Confluence Trunk" key="CONFFUNC" expand="plans">

The URL in the response looks a bit funny, because it has capital HTTPS in it:

* HTTPS://confluence-bamboo.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/project/CONFFUNC

Interestingly enough, it also appears in the UI. See the attached screenshot of the Bamboo base URL configuration. The description for this field has "HTTPS://" at the start as well.
